title: Paul Allen’s Beverly Hills Development Site Lists for $110 Million
text:
A 120-acre lot owned by the estate of the late Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen is back on the market.

Text size

A sprawling swath of undeveloped land in Beverly Hills owned by the estate of the late Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen has made its way back to the market with a $110 million price tag.

The 120-acre site—roughly the same size as Vatican City—dubbed The Enchanted Hill, listed Thursday. It first tested the market waters with a heftier $150 million asking price last year.

More: Glammed Up Pierre Hotel Apartment Lists for $65M

The tech billionaire and philanthropist, who died last October at 65, purchased the land in 1997 for roughly $20 million and demolished an existing home on the property, according to the Wall Street Journal.

The site is now owned by a trust controlled by Allen’s sister, Jody, records with PropertyShark show.

The lot offers the opportunity to “develop a single-family compound with multiple guest homes,” or a buyer could subdivide the lot and develop a gated community, according to a news release from listing brokerage Hilton & Hyland.

Any future compound has the space to include a state-of-the-art fitness and wellness center, an entertainment complex, a sports arena, world-class equestrian facilities and a winery, the release said.

During Allen’s ownership, he embarked on infrastructure improvements to the site, including the addition of a one-mile private street, utilities, and two separate gated entrances.

The Paul G. Allen Family Foundation, which could not be immediately reached for comment, continues to own and operate Allen’s catalog of professional sports teams, including the Seattle Seahawks.

The parcel is among the assets that Allen’s estate has listed for sale, including his megayacht, Octopus, that hit the market in September for more than $300 million, Mansion Global previously reported.

At 414 feet, Octopus can accommodate up to 26 guests across 13 cabins in addition to a crew of 60. It has multiple lounges, a library, a bar, a pool and a spa. There’s even a basketball court on the below deck, a glass-bottomed observation lounge, an eight-person submarine, helipads and a garage large enough to store an SUV and two helicopters.

The Los Angeles Times first reported the listing.

This article originally appeared in Mansion Global.
description: The late Microsoft co-founder and owner of the Seattle Seahawks bought the 120-acre parcel in Los Angeles in 1997
